body: You can achieve this by definining your own composed annotation and listing all extensions in one or multiple `@ExtendWith` annotations on that annotation definition. Would that work in your use case?

> This works beautifully.

Glad to hear that meets your needs!

> I wasn't able to find this feature in the user guide or javadoc.

[Support for meta-annotations](https://junit.org/junit5/docs/current/user-guide/#writing-tests-meta-annotations) is documented in the User Guide; however, we don't explicitly state that a custom composed annotation is a good technique for composing extension registration.

In addition, the Javadoc for some annotations states that JUnit Jupiter annotations may be used as meta-annotations; however, the [Javadoc for `@ExtendWith`](https://junit.org/junit5/docs/current/api/org.junit.jupiter.api/org/junit/jupiter/api/extension/ExtendWith.html) does not.

So, we could certainly add some documentation for this technique.

> So, we could certainly add some documentation for this technique.

I agree.

repository.name: junit-framework

body: I've submitted #2373 to address this. @ghunteranderson Do you think you would have found this and it would have helped?

@marcphilipp Nice! That's the section I opened first when I was looking for a solution. Definitely helpful :)
Thanks for helping with this so quickly.
